page_analysis.text_content:
Contextual garage placement
Contextual garage placement applies if, and only if, there is a predominant neighborhood pattern.
How to determine if contextual garage placement applies (using Fig 32 below as an example)
Note:
• If block is more than 600' long, consider only lots with in 600' or the 10 lots closest to the subject lot
• If subject lot is a corner lot, consider the pattern on the street that the subject garage faces
Exclude the following types of lots:
• Flag lot (C)
• Multi-family use of 3+ units (G)
• Corner lots (A & H)
The remaining lots including the subject lot, contribute to the determination.
Note:
• If block more than 600' long, consider only lots within 600' or 10 closest lots.
• If subject lot is a corner lot, consider the pattern on the street that the garage faces
Divide the remaining lots, including the subject lot, into two categories:
1. Front-half pattern lots
• lots with garage in front half of the lot (F)
2. Rear-half pattern lots
• lots with garage in the rear half of the lot (B & D) and
• lots with no garage (E) (counts as a rear-pattern lot)
Determine which pattern category is predominant i.e., into which category more than half of the lots fall.
Front half
Rear half
The contextual-garage-placement regulation DOES apply. Projects on this block must place the garage in the rear half of the lot.
Fig 32 Example of a block on which the contextual garage placement regulation applies

visual_elements.description: A flowchart illustrating the process of determining if contextual garage placement applies. It starts with excluding certain lot types, then categorizing remaining lots into 'Front-half pattern lots' and 'Rear-half pattern lots', and finally determining if a predominant pattern exists. If a predominant pattern is found, the contextual garage placement regulation applies, requiring garages to be placed in the rear half of the lot.

Figure 32: An example block layout showing various lots (A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H) with houses and garages. Some lots are marked with an 'X' indicating exclusion. Lot C is a flag lot, Lot G is a multi-family unit, and Lots A and H are corner lots. Lot F has a garage in the front half. Lots B and D have garages in the rear half. Lot E has no garage. The figure visually represents the different lot types and garage placements discussed in the text.

technical_specifications.parameter: Number of closest lots to consider

subheadings: Contextual garage placement applies if, and only if, there is a predominant neighborhood pattern.
How to determine if contextual garage placement applies (using Fig 32 below as an example)
Exclude the following types of lots:
The remaining lots including the subject lot, contribute to the determination.
Divide the remaining lots, including the subject lot, into two categories:
Determine which pattern category is predominant i.e., into which category more than half of the lots fall.
The contextual-garage-placement regulation DOES apply. Projects on this block must place the garage in the rear half of the lot.
Fig 32 Example of a block on which the contextual garage placement regulation applies

qualifiers.text: If block is more than 600' long
If subject lot is a corner lot
The remaining lots including the subject lot, contribute to the determination.
Determine which pattern category is predominant i.e., into which category more than half of the lots fall.

conditions.text: or the 10 lots closest to the subject lot
consider the pattern on the street that the subject garage faces
conditions.threshold_value: pattern on the street that the subject garage faces

conditions.text: lots with garage in front half of the lot (F)
lots with garage in the rear half of the lot (B & D)
lots with no garage (E) (counts as a rear-pattern lot)
more than half of the lots fall [into a pattern category]
Projects on this block must place the garage in the rear half of the lot.
conditions.threshold_value: garage in the rear half of the lot

logical_relationships.expression: IF (block is more than 600' long) THEN (consider only lots within 600' OR the 10 lots closest to the subject lot)
IF (subject lot is a corner lot) THEN (consider the pattern on the street that the subject garage faces)
Exclude (Flag lot (C) AND Multi-family use of 3+ units (G) AND Corner lots (A & H))
Rear-half pattern lots are (lots with garage in the rear half of the lot (B & D) OR lots with no garage (E))
IF (more than half of the lots fall into a pattern category) THEN (that category is predominant)
IF (there is a predominant neighborhood pattern) THEN (contextual garage placement regulation DOES apply)
IF (contextual-garage-placement regulation DOES apply) THEN (Projects on this block must place the garage in the rear half of the lot)

execution_sequence.action: Evaluate block length and subject lot type to determine scope of lots to consider.
Exclude specified types of lots from consideration.
Categorize remaining lots (including the subject lot) into 'Front-half pattern lots' or 'Rear-half pattern lots'.
Determine if a predominant pattern category exists (more than half of the lots fall into one category).
If a predominant pattern is found, the contextual garage placement regulation applies.
If the regulation applies, projects on the block must place garages in the rear half of the lot.
